candidates.title: build: bump open from 5.0.1 to 5.1.0
candidates.body:
Bumps [open](https://github.com/Byron/open-rs) from 5.0.1 to 5.1.0.
Release notes

Sourced from open's releases.

v5.1.0

New Features

  • use ShellExecuteW for detached spawning on Windows

Commit Statistics

  • 3 commits contributed to the release.
  • 2 days passed between releases.
  • 1 commit was understood as conventional.
  • 0 issues like '(#ID)' were seen in commit messages

Commit Details

  • Uncategorized
    • Merge pull request #91 from amrbashir/feat/windows/detachded-using-shellexecutew (b268647)
    • Split into two functions for better readability (4506b2f)
    • Use ShellExecuteW for detached spawning on Windows (191cb0e)

v5.0.2

Other

  • use PATH to find launcher Redox has moved the launcher from /ui/bin to /usr/bin. Just use the PATH to locate it, so any future changes in location don't break this crate.

Commit Statistics

  • 2 commits contributed to the release.
  • 97 days passed between releases.
  • 1 commit was understood as conventional.
  • 0 issues like '(#ID)' were seen in commit messages

Commit Details

  • Uncategorized
    • Merge pull request #89 from jackpot51/patch-1 (0a25651)
    • Use PATH to find launcher (a583658)

    • Split into two functions for better readability (4506b2f)
    • Use ShellExecuteW for detached spawning on Windows (191cb0e)

candidates.title: build: bump tempfile from 3.10.0 to 3.10.1
candidates.body:
Bumps [tempfile](https://github.com/Stebalien/tempfile) from 3.10.0 to 3.10.1.
Changelog

Sourced from tempfile's changelog.

3.10.1

  • Handle potential integer overflows in 32-bit systems when seeking/truncating "spooled" temporary files past 4GiB (2³²).
  • Handle a theoretical 32-bit overflow when generating a temporary file name larger than 4GiB. Now it'll panic (on allocation failure) rather than silently succeeding due to wraparound.

Thanks to @​stoeckmann for finding and fixing both of these issues.

Commits
  • 094c115 chore: release 3.10.1
  • 56c5934 Fix integer overflows and truncation (#278)
  • 5a949d6 chore: 2021 edition (#276)
  • See full diff in compare view

candidates.title: build: bump opentelemetry-semantic-conventions from 0.13.0 to 0.14.0
candidates.body:
Bumps [opentelemetry-semantic-conventions](https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-rust) from 0.13.0 to 0.14.0.
Release notes

Sourced from opentelemetry-semantic-conventions's releases.

v0.14.0

Added

  • Adding a dynamic dispatch to Aggregator Selector #497
  • Add global::force_flush_tracer_provider #512
  • Add config max_attributes_per_event and max_attributes_per_link #521
  • Add dropped attribute counts to events and links #529

Changed

  • Remove unnecessary clone in Key type #491
  • Remove #[must_use] from set_tracer_provider #501
  • Rename remaining usage of default_sampler to sampler #509
  • Use current span for SDK-less context propagation #510
  • Always export span batch when limit reached #519
  • Rename message events to events #530
  • Update resource merge behaviour #537
  • Ignore links with invalid context #538

Removed

  • Remove remote span context #508
  • Remove metrics quantiles #525

Fixed

  • Allow users to use custom export kind selector #526

Performance

  • Improve simple span processor performance #502
  • Local span perf improvements #505
  • Reduce string allocations where possible #506
Commits
  • 133ab27 Prepare for 0.14.0 release (#548)
  • e240f1d semantic-conventions: Update to spec version 1.3.0 (#547)
  • b84f993 Remove default surf features (#546)
  • f74705c fix: lint issues in 1.52.0 (#543)
  • 92a0d85 feat: add an example on how to config multiple span processors. (#539)
  • b3623ab feat: ignore links with invalid context (#538)
  • 3a8123c Update resource merge behaviour (#537)
  • a9f1453 fix: update metrics proto and metric transformation. (#535)
  • 3ff1802 Rename message events to events (#530)
  • 4e7613b Add dropped attribute counts to events and links (#529)
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

candidates.title: feat: time-limited journey traces
candidates.body:
This PR improves the host and project journeys. Since they are represented as traces, it is desirable to limit the growth of those traces.

This PR let spans accumulate for 5 days for a given journey (not configurable for now). After that date:

 - A new project/host journey is started
 - Its top span contains a link to the previous journey so that we can navigate to the previous data
 - The journey still contains the project id / host name so that it is still possible to query for all the traces related to a given project if necessary
 - The trace id incorporates the date as `YYMMDD` so that we can quickly identify when the actions took place
 - The `YYMMDD` dates are created in 5 days buckets so that the creation of journeys is very deterministic, even 
   if user actions are executed from different nodes on different days.

candidates.title: fix(rust): put the tracing context field under a compilation flag
candidates.body: Which is not included in std for now, until we know how to decode that field on the Controller.

candidates.title: feat: enable tracing by default
candidates.body:
This PR enables tracing by default.

The biggest changes consists in:

 1. Checking if the OpenTelemetry collector endpoint is accessible before deciding to enable tracing.
 2. Working around some possible deadlocks in the tracing library around shutdown behaviour.
 3. Refactoring the setup of commands so that
    - The setup code is easier to navigate.
    - Environment variables are only read once to build the logging/tracing configuration.

**The `OCKAM_TRACING` environment variable is to set to `false` by default in that PR. Once we will have tested tracing well enough, I will open a PR to set it to `true`**.

## Endpoint accessibility

We want to both enable tracing by default, and make sure that the command line stays responsive if the endpoint is not accessible or misconfigured.

Tracing is only enabled if the endpoint can be accessed with a TCP connection:

 - A default connection timeout of `500ms` is used. This is the result of experimenting with
     - An accessible endpoint, which should shown as available in that time or earlier.
     - An inaccessible endpoint, which should be shown as unavailable in that time or earlier.
 - If `quiet` is set to `true` then a message is displayed when tracing is not available.
   
## Deadlocks

The deadlock issue is opened [here](https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-rust/issues/1395). The workaround in this PR is to have a `LogProcessor` and a `SpanProcessor` which just flush on shutdown.

## Refactorings

### `ockam_api::config`

That module has been refactored to:

 - Remove the unused code for `atomic`, `ConfigValues`, `Config`.
 - Put in `ockam_api::config` some environment variables types:
     - `DurationVar` to parse `Durations`.
     - `UrlVar` to parse `Url`s.
     - `BooleanVar` to parse boolean values.
     - `LevelVar` to parse log levels.

### `ockam_api::logs`

That module has been refactored into many other modules:

- `current_span` convenience functions to set attributes on the current span
- `default_values` constant values used by default to configure logging / tracing
- `env_variables` list of environment variables which can be used to configure logging / tracing
- `log_exporters` (resp. `span_exporters`) implementations for the `LogExporter` trait. So far there is only a `DecoratedLogExporter` implementation which is useful to quickly intercept exported logs
- `log_processors` (resp. `span_processors`) implementations for the `LogProcessor` trait. It contains a `NonBlockingLogProcessor` which decorates any `LogProcessor` to avoid doing a shutdown, since this can trigger deadlocks
- `logging_configuration` data type describing all the possible values for configuring logging and where to get them from.
- `logging_options` data types describing some configuration options for logging
- `setup` main place where we configure the logging and tracing layers
- `tracing_guard` maintains the logging / tracing resources alive while a command is executed, or a background node running.

### `ockam_command`

The top-level code for creating and running an `OckamCommand` was becoming too bloated. The following files have been created / modified:

- `arguments` contains helper methods to parse input arguments
- `command_events` creates user events when a command executes
- `command_global_opts` extracts in its own file the `CommandGlobalOpts` data type
- `global_args` extracts in its own file the `GlobalArgs` data type 
- `ockam_command` create the `CommandGlobalOpts`, sets up logging/tracing, and run the subcommand
- `ockam_subcommand` enum with all the top level commands: `node`, `project`, `identity`, etc...

candidates.title: build: bump chrono from 0.4.33 to 0.4.34
candidates.body:
Bumps [chrono](https://github.com/chronotope/chrono) from 0.4.33 to 0.4.34.
Release notes

Sourced from chrono's releases.

0.4.34

Notable changes

  • In chrono 0.4.34 we finished the work to make all methods const where doing so is supported by rust 1.61.
  • We renamed the Duration type to TimeDelta. This removes the confusion between chrono's type and the later Duration type in the standard library. It will remain available under the old name as a type alias for compatibility.
  • The Windows implementation of Local is rewritten. The new version avoids panics when the date is outside of the range supported by windows (the years 1601 to 30828), and gives more accurate results during DST transitions.
  • The Display format of TimeDelta is modified to conform better to ISO 8601. Previously it converted all values greater than 24 hours to a value with days. This is not correct, as doing so changes the duration from an 'accurate' to a 'nominal' representation to use ISO 8601 terms.

Fixes

  • Add missing range check in TimeDelta::milliseconds (#1385, thanks @​danwilliams)
  • Remove check for DurationExceedsTimestamp in DurationRound (#1403, thanks @​joroKr21)
  • Fix localized formatting with %X ((chronotope/pure-rust-locales#12, #1420)
  • Windows: base implementation on GetTimeZoneInformationForYear (#1017)

Additions

  • Add TimeDelta::try_milliseconds (#1385, thanks @​danwilliams)
  • Add TimeDelta::new (#1337)
  • Add StrftimeItems::{parse, parse_to_owned} and more documentation (#1184)
  • More standard traits and documentation for format::Locale (via chronotope/pure-rust-locales#8)

Changes

  • Rename Duration to TimeDelta, add type alias (#1406)
  • Make TimeDelta methods const (#1337)
  • Make remaining methods of NaiveDate, NaiveWeek, NaiveTime and NaiveDateTime const where possible (#1337)
  • Make methods on DateTime const where possible (#1400)
  • Make Display format of TimeDelta conform better to ISO 8601 (#1328)

Documentation

  • Fix the formatting of timestamp_micros's Example doc (#1338 via #1386, thanks @​emikitas)
  • Specify branch for GitHub Actions badge and fix link (#1388)
  • Don't mention some deprecated methods in docs (#1395)
  • Remove stray documentation from main (#1397)
  • Improved documentation of TimeDelta constructors (#1385, thanks @​danwilliams)

Internal

  • Switch branch names: 0.4.x releases are the main branch, work on 0.5 happens in the 0.5.x branch (#1390, #1402).
  • Don't use deprecated method in impl Arbitrary for DateTime and set up CI test (#1336)
  • Remove workaround for Rust < 1.61 (#1393)
  • Bump codecov/codecov-action from 3 to 4 (#1404)
  • Remove partial support for handling -0000 offset (#1411)
  • Move TOO_LONG error out of parse_internal (#1419)

Thanks to all contributors on behalf of the chrono team, @​djc and @​pitdicker!

Commits
  • dc19606 Prepare 0.4.34
  • 58a2149 Add StrftimeItems::parse_to_owned
  • 59eeb8c Add StrftimeItems::parse
  • 79de122 Add more documentation to StrftimeItems::new_with_locale
  • 5b7cf85 Add more documentation to StrftimeItems::new
  • be6af79 Make Display format of TimeDelta conform better to ISO 8601
  • d1cf0e9 Add test for issue 651
  • 0ef34e4 Extend test to more distant dates
  • fc67f3e Remove obsolete test
  • acb693a Windows: rewrite using GetTimeZoneInformationForYear
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

candidates.title: Propagate the tracing context at the level of ockam messages
candidates.body: This PR adds an optional `tracing_context` field to Ockam messages: - That field is serializes as a String [a propagated OpenTelemetry context ](https://opentelemetry.io/docs/specs/otel/context/api-propagators/). - The field is read on the Elixir side when a message arrives and is used as the root of the trace which processes the message (same thing when an Elixir node sends a message to the Rust side). - The similar field which was present on Request/Responses (one level above Ockam messages) is now removed. One scenario used to test this PR was the sending of an Ockam message to a background node. Here is an example of a trace: What we see is that: - The `Messages::send_message` function calls the `TcpSender` worker to send a message. - This message is received by the `TcpRcvProcessor` on the background node and forwarded to the `Echoer` service. - And the message is finally routed back to the caller. ## How does it work? The main idea is to be able to serialize a proper tracing context in a `TransportMessage`. In order to do this, we need to solve 3 issues: 1. The `OpenTelemetryContext` must contain the current trace id and the _latest_ span id. 2. The tracing context must be preserved across async boundaries, for example between command invocation (synchronous) and command execution (asynchronous) 3. When we make a `LocalMessage` (for example containing a `Request`) we need to set the proper tracing context, _and make sure that this tracing context is staying up to date_ until we create a `TransportMessage`. ### Correct `OpenTelemetry` context This is not entirely obvious because of some discrepancies between the `tracing` crate and the `opentelemetry` crate(s). Please read the comments [here](https://github.com/build-trust/ockam/blob/4cd4f3a236a44b734b9ff52d14e793e0d69e5e9d/implementations/rust/ockam/ockam_node/src/opentelemetry.rs#L35) for an explanation on how this was solved in a previous PR. ### Passing the tracing context across async boundaries This is solved by using the `with_context` function, for example [here](https://github.com/build-trust/ockam/pull/7574/files#diff-721ad94ae6660f5847f6671ca3e9d1843cc9e9f804e41b6ebf4350c645990ddbR86). Note that we pass an `opentelemetry::Context` which is retrieved from the `OpenTelemetry::current()` function which makes sure that the last created span id is referenced. There are currently other places in the code where `.with_context` is used, for example in `ockam_command/src/space/list.rs`. In this case we might not have the latest span id but this is not a problem since this code is called via the `embedded_node` function which sets the current context properly. ### Passing the tracing context intra-node There are 3 crucial places where the tracing context needs to be set and updated: - `LocalMessage::into_transport_message` when we create a `TransportMessage` from a `LocalMessage` containing the tracing context. Note that we call `local_message.tracing_context.update()` to make sure that the tracing context really contains the latest span id - `Context::send_from_address_impl`. This is where we create a `LocalMessage` when a worker sends a payload on a given route (the `.update()` method is also called here) - `WorkerRelay::recv_message`. Here we get the tracing context conveyed by the `LocalMessage` and: - set it on the worker context - use it (with `with_context) on the async call for `worker.handle_message` If any of these things are missing then we are breaking traces. ## Testing I have added 2 tests sending a "hello" message across 2 nodes, to and `Echoer` and back (with and without a secure channel). These tests check that we end-up with one trace, showing spans from both nodes, in a correct parent/child relationship: ```rust root ├── create tcp transport ├── create tcp transport └── TcpSendWorker::handle_message └── TcpRecvProcessor::process └── Echoer::handle_message └── TcpSendWorker::handle_message └── TcpRecvProcessor::process ``` These kind of tests have one drawback, they break if code is refactored, methods renamed etc... However without these tests it is very easy to break tracing and not realize it. ## Additional implementations notes - The `OpenTelemetry` code has been moved to the `ockam_core` crate to be close to the Ockam message protocol. - A `Messages` interface has been refactored for both a `BackgroundNodeClient` and the `NodeManager` in order to instrument a span showing the invocation of the `send_message` function when running `ockam message send` - Similarly I extracted an `Outlets` trait to add a span for the outlet creation (this is [something that we needed to do anyway](https://github.com/build-trust/ockam/issues/6698))

candidates.title: feat(rust): support policies for resource types
candidates.body:
- Add support for global policies in the `policy create` command. The information about whether the resource is global is derived from the resource name to guarantee backward compatibility. The global policy is used within a given node across resources of the same type (i.e. each node has its global policies).
- Change `--expression` argument on `tcp-inlet|outlet create` to `--allow`.
- The `--alias` argument of `tcp-outlet create` has been removed in favor of `--from`
- Refactor internals of policy commands to have the same structure and produce the same output as other commands
- Refactor struct returned by policy API endpoints.
